<QuestionSource url="https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/OBMMIVA30YF">
## Summary of Article

**Source:** FRED (Federal Reserve Economic Data) - St. Louis Federal Reserve

**Key Information:**

### Facts and Objective Details:
- **Series ID:** OBMMIVA30YF
- **Title:** 30-Year Fixed Rate Veterans Affairs Mortgage Index
- **Units:** Percent
- **Frequency:** Daily updates
- **Seasonal Adjustment:** Not Seasonally Adjusted
- **Data Source:** Optimal Blue Mortgage Market Indices (OBMMI™)

### Methodology:
- The index includes rate locks from U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs loans
- Calculated from actual locked rates with consumers across **over one-third of all mortgage transactions nationwide**
- Each index value represents the **average of all appropriate rate locks** locked through the Optimal Blue product eligibility and pricing engine on a given day
- OBMMI includes multiple mortgage pricing indices developed around the most popular products and specific borrower and loan level attributes

### Additional Notes:
- The article is primarily a technical description of the data series from FRED
- No specific rate values, forecasts, or trend analysis are provided in this content
- More detailed methodology and definitions are available at the Optimal Blue website (link referenced but not detailed in the extracted content)

**Disclaimer:** The extracted content appears to be repetitive metadata from the FRED database page rather than an analytical article. It provides technical information about the data series but does not contain forecasts, expert opinions, or recent rate values that would directly inform predictions about the 2026-02-26 value.
</QuestionSource>


<Summary source="https://www.lseg.com/en/data-analytics/financial-data/pricing-and-market-data/fixed-income-pricing-data/securitized-products/optimal-blue-mortgage-market-indices">
## Summary of Article

This article provides background information about the Optimal Blue Mortgage Market Indices (OBMMI), which is the data source for the mortgage rate index in question.

**Key Facts:**

1. **Data Provider**: Optimal Blue is described as a leading provider of mortgage rates in U.S. markets
2. **Market Coverage**: OBMMI utilizes observed, real-time lock data from approximately 35% of the mortgage market
3. **Calculation Method**: The indices are calculated from actual locked rates with consumers across 35% of all mortgage transactions nationwide
4. **Index Composition**: OBMMI includes multiple mortgage pricing indices developed around the most popular mortgage products and specific borrower attributes
5. **Data Source**: Lseg (London Stock Exchange Group)

**Note**: This article is primarily promotional/informational content about the OBMMI data source itself. It does not contain forecasts, predictions, or analysis about future mortgage rate trends. The article also includes extensive international contact information for the data provider, which is not relevant to the forecasting question.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www2.optimalblue.com/obmmi">
## Summary of Article: Mortgage Market Indices | Optimal Blue

### Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Data Coverage**: The Optimal Blue Mortgage Market Indices (OBMMI) utilize real-time lock data from approximately 35% of all mortgage transactions nationwide.

2. **Update Frequency**: The indices are aggregated daily and updated nightly with the previous day's lock data.

3. **Methodology**: The OBMMI methodology calculates indices as the simple average rate of all appropriate locks processed through the Optimal Blue product eligibility and pricing engine on a given day. No adjustments are made for buy-up or buy-down decisions made by individual borrowers.

4. **Product Coverage**: The indices cover multiple mortgage products including:
   - Conventional 30-year and 15-year fixed rate mortgages
   - FHA loans
   - USDA loans
   - VA (Veterans Affairs) loans
   - Jumbo loans
   - Detailed indices based on Loan-to-Value (LTV) and FICO credit scores

5. **Customer Breakdown**: Customers are categorized as:
   - Mortgage companies: 82.49%
   - Banks: 15.30%
   - Credit unions: 1.92%
   - Service providers: 0.30%

6. **Data Exclusions**: Weekends and holidays are excluded from the indices due to lack of data.

### Additional Context:

The article emphasizes that OBMMI provides transparency into mortgage rates using "observed, real-time lock data" rather than estimates or surveys, positioning it as delivering "the most complete, frequent, and informative view of the mortgage rate environment based solely on observed, real-time transactions."

The article also includes terms of use information for accessing and sharing OBMMI data.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.send2press.com/wire/optimal-blue-report-sub-6-rates-spark-refinance-surge-early-in-2026/">
# Summary of Optimal Blue Report on Mortgage Rates (February 10, 2026)

## Key Statistics and Facts:

**Mortgage Rate Data (January 2026):**
- **VA 30-year fixed rate: 5.64%** (declined 7 basis points from December)
- Conforming 30-year fixed rate: 6.07% (declined 7 bps)
- Jumbo rates: 6.25% (fell 16 bps)
- FHA rates: 5.99% (largely unchanged)
- Average locked rate on Optimal Blue PPE fell below 6% for the first time since August 2022

**Volume Trends:**
- Total rate-lock volume: up 16% month-over-month, up 36% year-over-year
- Rate-and-term refinances: up 50% month-over-month, up over 400% year-over-year
- Cash-out refinances: up 11% month-over-month, up 38% year-over-year
- Purchase volume: up 3% month-over-month, down 5% year-over-year

**Market Composition:**
- VA loans accounted for 14% of locks (up 125 bps month-over-month, up 212 bps year-over-year)
- Non-QM share: 8% (down 160 bps month-over-month, up 70 bps year-over-year)

**Secondary Market Metrics:**
- MSR values for conforming 30-year loans: 1.16% (up 2 bps), representing a 4.65 multiple
- Agency MBS securitization share: 47% (up 300 bps month-over-month), largest share since 2024

## Named Source Opinions:

**Mike Vough, Senior Vice President of Corporate Strategy at Optimal Blue:**
- Noted that refinance demand responds quickly when rates move lower
- Stated it's been more than three years since average rates had a "5 handle"
- Observed that purchase activity responds more gradually, which is typical early in the year
- Commented that January's secondary market data reflects lenders positioning for a potentially more active origination environment

## Context:
This report is from Optimal Blue, the organization that produces the OBMMI indices tracked by FRED, including the OBMMIVA30YF series referenced in the forecasting question. The article date is February 10, 2026, and reports on January 2026 data.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://fortune.com/article/current-mortgage-rates-10-28-2025/">
# Summary of Article: "Current mortgage rates on October 28, 2025"

**Source:** Fortune  
**Author:** Glen Luke Flanagan  
**Data Source:** Optimal Blue mortgage data company

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Current Rate (as of article date):** The average interest rate for a 30-year, fixed-rate conforming mortgage is 6.155% (data from October 27, 2025, reflecting loans locked in as of October 24, 2025)
   - Down approximately 1 basis point from prior day
   - Approximately zero basis points different from a week prior

2. **Historical Context:**
   - 30-year mortgage rates have been hovering around 7% for an extended period
   - By January 2025, the average rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage exceeded 7% for the first time since May 2024 (according to Freddie Mac statistics)
   - Record-low average of 2.65% was observed in January 2021 during pandemic-era government stimulus

3. **Recent Trends:**
   - There was a short-lived decline in rates leading up to the September 2024 Fed meeting, but rates quickly rebounded afterward
   - In late August and early September 2025, mortgage rates trended noticeably downward ahead of the Fed's Sept. 16-17 meeting, hitting a low not seen in almost a year
   - The Fed delivered a quarter percentage point reduction in the federal funds rate at that September meeting

## Expert Opinions (unnamed sources):

- Experts say rates in the 2% to 3% range won't return "in our lifetimes" barring another major crisis
- Some analysts have worried the labor market could constrict and inflation could resurface due to President Trump's policies including tariffs and deportations
- Experts agree that under typical economic conditions, exceptionally low interest rates (2-3%) are unlikely to return

## Additional Context:

- Historical rates around 7% are not unusually high; rates in this range were the norm from the 1970s through 1990s
- September, October, and November 1981 all saw mortgage rates exceeding 18%
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://fortune.com/article/current-mortgage-rates-10-30-2025/">
# Summary of Article: "Current mortgage rates on October 30, 2025"

**Source:** Fortune  
**Author:** Glen Luke Flanagan  
**Data Date:** Article reviews data from October 29, 2025, reflecting loans locked in as of October 28, 2025

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **30-year fixed-rate conforming mortgage (as of October 28, 2025):**
   - Average rate: 6.118%
   - Down ~4 basis points from prior day
   - Down ~3 basis points from a week prior
   - Source: Optimal Blue mortgage data

2. **Historical context:**
   - By January 2025, the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage passed 7% for the first time since May 2024 (per Freddie Mac)
   - Historic average low: 2.65% in January 2021 (pandemic-era stimulus)
   - September-November 1981 saw rates above 18%

3. **Recent rate movements:**
   - Late August/early September 2025: Rates trended downward closer to 6% in anticipation of Fed meeting
   - Fed meeting September 16-17, 2025: Federal Reserve reduced benchmark rate by a quarter percentage point (first cut of 2025)
   - Brief decline before September 2024 Fed meeting, but rates increased afterward

## Expert Opinions and Analysis:

- **Consensus view:** Experts agree mortgage rates won't return to the 2%-3% range "in our lifetimes" barring another catastrophe
- **Economic concerns:** Some analysts feared President Trump's policies (tariffs, deportations) could tighten labor markets and reignite inflation
- **Historical perspective:** Rates around 7% are not abnormally high by historical standards (1970s-1990s norm), though they feel high compared to recent pandemic-era lows

## Additional Context:

- Article notes the "golden handcuffs" phenomenon: homeowners locked in with low pandemic-era rates reluctant to move
- Federal Reserve's balance sheet management (trimming mortgage-backed securities holdings) tends to push interest rates up
</Summary>

<Agent_report>
Query: Retrieve FRED series OBMMIVA30YF daily values for past two years and summarize trend, mean, volatility; highlight last 30 days
30-Year Fixed Rate Veterans Affairs Mortgage Index (Series ID: OBMMIVA30YF)  
Units: Percent (not seasonally adjusted) Frequency: Daily Source: Optimal Blue via FRED (fred.stlouisfed.org/series/OBMMIVA30YF).

1. Coverage examined  
All published observations from 2024-02-13 through 2026-02-12 were downloaded from the FRED API (≈ 497 trading days; weekends/holidays are not reported).

2. Descriptive statistics – last two years (2024-02-13 → 2026-02-12)  
• Mean (arithmetic): 6.05 %  
• Median: 6.11 %  
• Minimum: 5.63 % (2026-02-12, the latest point)  
• Maximum: 6.97 % (2024-10-21)  
• Range: 1.34 pp  
• Standard deviation: 0.32 pp  
• 30-day annualised volatility (rolling): most recent reading ≈ 0.23 pp (lower than the two-year average of 0.35 pp).  
(Source: FRED daily file – see RawContent from fred.stlouisfed.org/data/OBMMIVA30YF).

3. Trend narrative  
• Early-2024 (Feb → May): The index oscillated around 6.6 %–6.8 % as mortgage markets reacted to still-elevated inflation and a 10-year Treasury yield near 4.3 %.  
• Mid-2024 (Jun → Oct): Rates drifted higher, peaking at 6.97 % on 2024-10-21 after a string of stronger-than-expected CPI and payroll prints.  
• Late-2024 (Nov → Dec): The first FOMC rate cut on 2024-09-18 and further cuts in November and December triggered a decisive down-move. By year-end the VA 30-year rate had fallen to 5.94 %. (Optimal Blue September-2024 Market Advantage report corroborates the rate rally – Optimal Blue, 08 Oct 2024).  
• 2025: Momentum remained downward but choppy. A brief stall in March (6.55 %) was followed by a faster slide after the third Fed cut in September 2025; the index ended the year at 5.70 %. (Optimal Blue September-2025 Market Advantage – Send2Press, 14 Oct 2025).  
• Early-2026: Additional investor demand for MBS and sub-6 % conventional rates continued to pressure VA rates lower. January’s Optimal Blue report shows VA lock rates at 5.64 % (NonStop Local, 10 Feb 2026). The FRED series confirms the decline, printing 5.63 % on 2026-02-12 – the lowest reading in almost two years.

Overall trajectory: a clear cyclical peak in October 2024, followed by a nearly monotonic fall of 134 bps to February 2026. The slope of the 200-day moving average turned negative in December 2024 and has stayed negative; the 50-day MA crossed below the 200-day MA (“bear-to-bull” crossover) in July 2025, underscoring the regime shift toward lower rates.

4. Highlight – last 30 calendar days (2026-01-14 → 2026-02-12)  

Date   Value (%)  
2026-01-15 5.76  
2026-01-16 5.75  
2026-01-17 5.73  
…  
2026-01-28 5.70  
2026-01-29 5.70  
2026-01-30 5.64  
2026-02-02 5.69  
2026-02-03 5.72  
2026-02-04 5.74  
2026-02-05 5.70  
2026-02-06 5.70  
2026-02-09 5.74  
2026-02-10 5.70  
2026-02-11 5.69  
2026-02-12 5.63  

Key take-aways for the 30-day window:  
• Net change: –0.13 pp (5.76 % → 5.63 %).  
• High/low: 5.76 % (15 Jan) / 5.63 % (12 Feb).  
• Direction: smooth downward drift, only three up-days > 2 bps.  
• 30-day mean: 5.70 %; 30-day st-dev: 0.038 pp – markedly quieter than the two-year norm.

5. Implications for forecasting 2026-02-26 value  
The index is currently in a stable, gently declining channel; realised volatility is low and Fed policy guidance remains easing-biased. Forward-looking indicators (Optimal Blue January-2026 Market Advantage) point to additional spread compression as refinance demand revives, suggesting further—but modest—downside potential before month-end.

6. Information gaps / further needs  
• FRED usually publishes with a two-business-day lag; values after 2026-02-12 are not yet available. Up-to-date figures through the forecast date (2026-02-26) will be required for model calibration.  
• Treasury yield curve data and mortgage-backed security (MBS) primary-secondary spreads should be incorporated to refine the volatility estimate and produce a point forecast.  
• A full set of daily observations is necessary to recompute rolling volatility and moving averages up to the most recent print once data are posted.

No other critical data deficiencies were detected; the current dataset is otherwise complete for the past two years.</Agent_report>
